componenttext: Generally, Robin, when we introduce a game from an introduction to where we are pretty completely rolled out at least through the bulk of it, usually takes about six months in the normal course. And then I think that’s about what we’re seeing. We continually try and accelerate that wherever we can so there have been a lot of initiatives between manufacturing and the field service organization to accelerate that wherever we can, but it is kind of a function of how many people we have.

headline: International Game Technology, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Hi, good afternoon. Hey, Eric or Patti, maybe you could just broadly tell us what your customers are saying out there. Because I guess I’m struggling with some level of replacement sales, how much they are really interested in replacing machine with sor
componenttext: Hi, good afternoon. Hey, Eric or Patti, maybe you could just broadly tell us what your customers are saying out there. Because I guess I’m struggling with some level of replacement sales, how much they are really interested in replacing machine with sort of what are the gating issues that are holding them back and what would make them accelerate or decelerate the replacement sales who are out on the field a lot, I thought it’d be good to hear from you. Secondly, on the incentive, it sounds like you are giving a few more incentives to get to sort of buy a machine then given how many great machines you have out there better products in a couple of years what’s the rationale for doing that?

headline: International Game Technology, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, so, let me talk first about my view of the customer sentiment and then I’ll let Eric add his thoughts as well. I think my view and my researches with customers is that they see the value in the new products, they see the value in the MLD products,
componenttext: Yes, so, let me talk first about my view of the customer sentiment and then I’ll let Eric add his thoughts as well. I think my view and my researches with customers is that they see the value in the new products, they see the value in the MLD products, they see a need to refresh their floors, and the biggest obstacle is their capital budgets. I mean they are under the same pressure we’re all under to manage their returns, their shareholders and so, it’s really in my mind just restricted capital budget and I think I indicated before Steve, when we talked there is a lot more planning going on right now than there is buying but I think when the capital budgets you will see a bit more buying moving up. So anything you want to add?

headline: International Game Technology, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: I have similar conversations with customers along those lines. They want to refresh their floors, we’ve missed the whole cycle, they see that their floors need that reinvestment, but the capital budgets being controlled so tightly they just don’t have
componenttext:
I have similar conversations with customers along those lines. They want to refresh their floors, we’ve missed the whole cycle, they see that their floors need that reinvestment, but the capital budgets being controlled so tightly they just don’t have the opportunity. With that we’ve really focused on how we can facilitate the refreshing their floors and minimize the capital budgets.
So one of the reasons why the dynamics package meet sense to us and actually turned out to be very successful is that it combines the refreshing of two older beings which are susceptible to replacement because they are older, they are older being, at the same time you never change the minimal capital budget, they do have to buy in the next generation platform. It’s kind of a win-win, you invest in the future but you solidify the past. It made a lot of sense because these 80960 game themes that we put out the convergence themes don’t cost very much. It’s $500 a piece so $1,000 total. The other area that we’re focused on because the capital budgets are so limited is placing our MegaJackpots themes on the floor, because it’s capital less to the customers, it refreshes the floor, that’s need refreshing and is a lot of energy behind a new labels, so everybody seems to be excited about that, we’re having a good run at it because of that.

headline: International Game Technology, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: And I think Steve, just getting to your second question was I think it is important to drive and that is that the obstacle between where we are in increased volume has nothing, but it has very little to do with game performance. It’s about capital budge
componenttext: And I think Steve, just getting to your second question was I think it is important to drive and that is that the obstacle between where we are in increased volume has nothing, but it has very little to do with game performance. It’s about capital budgets. So what we’ve to do is help our customer address their biggest strategic issues that we see the dynamics package as strategic, it does protect our installed base and protect our position on the floor, at a point in time, when the replacement environment is at such low level. So we see it as a strategic, that combine with our product performance on the MLD product in particular we’ve been just very strategic in the market.

headline: International Game Technology, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Italy, I think the size in the market hasn’t really changed. Timing I think has moved out. I think if you talk to everybody involve there, including the operators and sales. I will tell you that it’s going slower than they thought. The reason for that
componenttext:
Italy, I think the size in the market hasn’t really changed. Timing I think has moved out. I think if you talk to everybody involve there, including the operators and sales. I will tell you that it’s going slower than they thought. The reason for that is there is not one consistent system solution been offer there and invariably as one person providing maybe the game system but they have the interface to someone else’s is monitoring systems so there’s fair amount of engineering, engineering work that’s happened to go on, on the part of everybody that’s supplying there.
For us, I don’t know if we have much, I think we announced two deals around the time of the London Show that were both done by our UK subsidiary. I don’t know if we have anything yet today to talk about the European operation caters to where they are more casino oriented product. And so probably later this year late part of the summer maybe before the end of the calendar year you might see some shipments starting to go in there.

headline: International Game Technology, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: I think I will give you my comments and Pat will reply to your request. I think a bundling again the bundling and packaging is focused on splitting the activity between converting the old install base and selling new machines. And as we move out of this l
componenttext: I think I will give you my comments and Pat will reply to your request. I think a bundling again the bundling and packaging is focused on splitting the activity between converting the old install base and selling new machines. And as we move out of this level of replacement cycle into the next level of replacement cycle where customers becoming less focused on refreshing the old machines and they become more focused on replacing them, then the dynamics products kind of disappears for us. So if you look at the ASP on a standalone product less discount looking back on the conversion, you ‘d still find the same levels of ASP that we’ve been enjoying but you’re getting the discounts of a convergent package. So they move away from combining convergent with new purchases you will find the ASPs will reflect that.

componenttext: I think it’s going to become more steady and that’s why in Q1, we are able to early adopt a new, there were two new EITF that come out, both doing with revenue recognition and as you saw this quarter made it easier for us to bifurcate the hardwire and the software so that that we were not having to defer revenue on machines where there really is value earlier than when maybe a system for example, most complicated one. It’s just getting better about making sure that the accounting folks are at the hip with the legal folks and the sales folks as we’re constructing deals rather than letting the deals get put together and then we get stuck having to live with whatever the accounting treatment is.

headline: International Game Technology, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Just a question for you, Patti. You brought in a lot of non-gaming people into the organization over the course of the last year. How was that cultural transformation at IGT tracking?
componenttext: Just a question for you, Patti. You brought in a lot of non-gaming people into the organization over the course of the last year. How was that cultural transformation at IGT tracking?

headline: International Game Technology, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: We have brought a lot of folks that don’t have wager based gaming experience. Chris Satchel brings a very long history in gaming from Microsoft to the company. So when you look at the senior management team it’s kind of split half and half, we have fo
componenttext:
We have brought a lot of folks that don’t have wager based gaming experience. Chris Satchel brings a very long history in gaming from Microsoft to the company. So when you look at the senior management team it’s kind of split half and half, we have folks who have been in the industry a very long time and we have new thinkers in the business, but I think with the right balance where the areas where gaming experience is very important from a product development perspective, from a technology investment perspective, from an intellectual property creation perspective, we have aired towards the side of protecting that gaming legacy and in areas of legal and compliance and sales and new media obviously we’ve been less so.
So culturally going well so far, I think again, we’re really relying on both sides to do what they need them to do. The new eyes to really push and challenge why are we doing things this way and the legacy executives including all the legacy in place of IGT should really challenge and help understand why we do things certainly. I think what we’re finding as we’re working through that is we’re moving our decisions to the middle to balance of input from both sides of that equation.
So I would say at this point it’s going well, we’re starting to do some things differently and we’ve invested in marketing, really the third time in this company’s history, really Eric has created a marketing organization and thinks about the four Ps of marketing, in product and placement, promotion and price and bundling and packaging and our brand in ways that we haven’t been thinking about it, we think about routes to market differently than we thought about that before.
And I would say that some of our competitors have done a better job than we have over a lot several years, new thinking and challenges to status quo and we’re at a point and not only our company, but in this industry where we’re destined to do more of that. So I would say at this point I would give a high marks and we’ll see who wears down whom first.

headline: International Game Technology, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: We have all intents and purposes what I would be interested to be five studios today, we have a system studio and then we have our floor games studios and we think less about quantity coming out each of the studios because each play a very different role,
componenttext:
We have all intents and purposes what I would be interested to be five studios today, we have a system studio and then we have our floor games studios and we think less about quantity coming out each of the studios because each play a very different role, that studio that is responsible for video poker product is less about quantity, frankly. And when you think about the game ops business, that’s really about return on capital. We have those folks focused on the performance of their games against the capital that IGT strand in the marketplace. So we don’t think about it is much, its quantity, frankly, as we think about each all that role that each studio plays in the market
Now, I would say always in every quarter you are going to have studios that play stronger than others and we have that at this particular time. That’s based on the needs of the business, less than the talent of the workforce. So when the needs of the business shift you do have to ride and push studios differently. And so we’re doing that. I would say it will never be equal because studios are studios and they are creative people so will never be equal but I think we had each studio playing the role that the company has defined for them to play. Eric, do you have anything to add to that?

headline: International Game Technology, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: No, I think it does trend, we have actually put a lot of discipline in the product management function in defining the type of the games we believe the marketplace is looking for and there is always it depends upon time, cycles in the marketplace, gaps in
componenttext: No, I think it does trend, we have actually put a lot of discipline in the product management function in defining the type of the games we believe the marketplace is looking for and there is always it depends upon time, cycles in the marketplace, gaps in our product portfolio. I think in the past we might have developed games based on probably a less disciplined manner so I think that as Patti mentioned as we define different requirements, different studios will play a more significant role for those requirements, but much more sophisticated approach to game development which we are finding to be very productive and probably more effective as we launch these products at the market.

componenttext: Possibly into that 80960 platform, but you have to keep in mind that we are now starting to get a fair number of AVPs, some of which are getting to be rather long data themselves that are better able to handle some of the new games coming down the line, so this is possible, Cameron. I think probably less so international, I think, international tends to lag the domestic market a little bit.

headline: International Game Technology, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: I think the other thing, Cameron, as you look forward into 2011, 2012 when you think about convergence, the notion of a convergent for IGT will change pretty dramatically from what today is kind of a hardware, firmware, software changed, over time being v
componenttext: I think the other thing, Cameron, as you look forward into 2011, 2012 when you think about convergence, the notion of a convergent for IGT will change pretty dramatically from what today is kind of a hardware, firmware, software changed, over time being various software configurable. So we will think about conversion differently going forward than we think about them today, as we go in to converting that only into our game ops business, but into some of the higher end AVP boxes, will be more of a software conversion than a hardware, firmware conversion.

headline: International Game Technology, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, operator, and good afternoon, everyone. Welcome to IGT's Second Quarter Fiscal 2010 Earnings Call. With me today are Patti Hart, our President and CEO; and Eric Tom, our Executive Vice President of Sales and Marketing. Before we begin, we wou
componenttext:
Thank you, operator, and good afternoon, everyone. Welcome to IGT's Second Quarter Fiscal 2010 Earnings Call. With me today are Patti Hart, our President and CEO; and Eric Tom, our Executive Vice President of Sales and Marketing. 
Before we begin, we would like to remind listeners that our discussion reflects management's views based on the marketplace environment as of today, April 22, 2010, and will include forward-looking statements including: Forecast of future performance and estimates of amounts not yet determinable; the potential for growth of existing and the opening of new markets for our products; play levels for an installed base of recurring revenue games as well as future prospects; and proposed new products, services, developments or business strategies.
Our future financial condition and results of operations, as well as our forward-looking statements, are subject to change into inherent known and unknown risks and uncertainties. We do not intend and undertake no obligation to update our forward-looking statements to reflect future events or circumstances. And you should not assume later in the quarter or the years that the comments we make today are still valid. Actual results may differ materially. Additional information about factors which could potentially impact our financial results is included in today's press release and our filings with the SEC, and included in our most recent annual report on Form 10-K and our reports on Form 10-Q filed during fiscal 2010. 
During this call, we may discuss certain non-GAAP financial measures in our press release and in our filings with the SEC, each of which is posted on our website at igt.com. You will find additional disclosures regarding any non-GAAP measures, including reconciliations of the measures with comparable GAAP measures. With that, I'll turn to the discussion of the business. 
This afternoon, IGT reported a second quarter results for fiscal 2010. Net income totaled $36 million or $0.12 per diluted share. This compares to $34 million and $0.11 per diluted share in the prior-year quarter. The current quarter included restructuring and inventory obsolescence charges of $18 million after-tax or $0.06 per diluted share. These are all primarily related to the decision to close our Japan operations as well as an impairment for intellectual property of $7 million with no tax benefits or $0.02 per diluted share, primarily due to uncertainties about how certain patents stayed in within our strategic direction.
The prior-year quarter included restructuring charges of $8 million, $5 million after-tax or $0.02 per diluted share. So excluding these charges mentioned above, second quarter adjusted net income was $61 million or $0.20 per diluted share for fiscal 2010, and $39 million or $0.13 per diluted share in fiscal 2009. Additionally, the second quarter comparability was affected by a number of notable items, the detail of which are broken out in our earnings press release, which went out earlier this afternoon.
The prior-year quarter includes certain restated amounts due to the required retrospective application of new accounting standards associated with our convertible debt. On a consolidated basis, our revenues for the second quarter were $498 million, of which 57% was generated from gaming operations and the other 43% from product sales, compared to $476 million for the same quarter last year.
For the six months ended March 31, 2010, consolidated revenues were $1 billion, compared to $1.1 billion in the same period last year. Consolidated gross profit and operating income for the quarter was $276 million and $95 million respectively, and $573 million and $235 million respectively for the six months ended March 31.
During the first fiscal quarter of 2010, we adopted new accounting standards to require a retrospective application to prior periods associated with our convertible debt and with equity classification of non-controlling interest. The retrospective adjustments are outlined in the supplemental schedule at the end of our press release. The new accounting standards for convertible debt resulted in reduced diluted EPS of $0.01 for the current quarter and $0.02 for the prior-year quarter.
Moving on to Gaming Operations. Game Op revenues were $285 million in the current quarter, which was up 3% sequentially but down 3% year-over-year. Approximately $5 million of the decrease in the revenues in the current quarter was attributed to property closures and the reduction of electronic charitable bingo terminals being operated in Alabama, compared to the same period last year. Gross margins were 62% for the quarter versus 59% in the prior-year quarter. Current quarter margins were positively impacted primarily by lower depreciation. We earned an average of $51.70 a share in revenue per unit per day, which is up 5% sequentially and down from $52.96 in the last year's second quarter.
Fiscal ended yield of 51 70 is an average of the various components of our broad and diverse installed base, comprised of our MegaJackpots, our Central Determination, Class II and lease ops units, all of which served distinct markets and have the unique yield characteristics. Lower year-over-year blended yield is the result of the continued shift towards lower yield in machines. 
IGT's installed base ended the second quarter at 58,800 units, down 2,500 units over the prior year and down 3,400 units compared to prior sequential quarter.  The decline in our installed base is primarily due to the reduction of electronic charitable bingo terminals being operated in Alabama. Approximately, 83% of our installed base is comprised of variable fee games, which earn a percentage of the machine's play levels rather than a fixed daily fee.
Moving to product sales. Product sales revenue totaled $213 million for the quarter, compared to $181 million in the prior year. Worldwide, we shipped 11,800 machines during the quarter, down from prior-year shipments of 12,700. Our machine revenues is comprised of gaming systems, game theme conversions, tables, parts and intellectual property fees came in at $72 million for the quarter or 34% of total product sales for the quarter, compared to $70 million and 38% of total product sales in the prior-year quarter.
Product sales gross margins were 46% for the quarter, down 200 basis points from the prior-year quarter, primarily due to higher obsolescence incurred in the current year quarter including write-downs related to the closure of our Japanese operations.
For a reconciliation of units shipped to equivalent units recognized, please see our earnings release. Units shipped for the current period reflect all units shipped to customers, which include units for which revenues have been deferred. Equivalent units recognized represent units recognized in revenues under Generally Accepted Accounting Principles during the quarter.
Taking a break in our product sales down, the domestic versus international. First, domestic product sales revenue totaled $124 million, a volume of 5,200 units recognized for the current quarter, compared to $127 million and 5,400 units recognized during the prior-year quarter. Domestic replacement units shipped totaled 4,100 for quarter, which is up 2,300 units from the prior year, and up 1,100 units sequentially. While we continue to have limited visibility around replacement demand, we are encouraged by the recent uptick in demand as well as the quality and innovation of our Product Sales segment.
Domestic new and expansion shipments totaled 800 units in the quarter, down 1,500 sequentially and down 2,900 units from the prior-year quarter due to the fact that there are just fewer new openings occurring this fiscal year. The prospective adoption of revenue recognition accounting standards related to certain software-enabled products and multi-element arrangements as of the beginning of the fiscal 2010 resulted in $13 million of revenues in the current quarter, which would have been recognized in later periods under the prior guidance.
Domestic non-machine revenue totaled $50 million in the quarter, down from $52 million in the prior quarter primarily due to lower systems revenues. Domestic average selling price was $14,300 for the second quarter, compared to $13,700 in the prior-year quarter. And Domestic average revenue per unit, computed on a equivalent unit basis, was 23,800 for the second quarter compared to 23,500 in the prior year. Both the ASP and the ARPU increases were due to the increase mix of MLDs [Multi-Layer Display] shipped and sold during the quarter.
We shipped 2,500 MLD units or 51% of total North American shipments in the second quarter, compared to 500 units or 8% of total North American shipments in the prior-year quarter. Sales of machines utilizing our AVP [Advanced Video Platform] technology now comprise 95% of total North American machines shipped during the second quarter. The trend we expect to continue as our legacy for-sale products continue to be phased out.
International product sales revenue totaled $89 million on volume of 7,400 units recognized for the current quarter, compared to $54 million on 7,100 units recognized in the prior-year quarter. Our international markets benefited from the opening of Resorts World Sentosa in Singapore, improved sales in Europe and favorable foreign currency exchange.
International non-machine sales were $23 million, up from $18 million in the prior quarter. Quarter was driven primarily by increases in systems revenue. International ASPs were 9,000 for the second quarter, compared to 5,200 in the prior-year quarter. And international ARPU, computed on equivalent units recognized basis, in the second quarter was 12,100, up 59% over the prior-year quarter. Both the ASP and the ARPU increases were due to a more favorable geographic product mix, i.e. more heavily weighted with casinos-style products.
Total product sales gross margins for the quarter were 46%, down 200 basis points from the prior-year quarter. As the quarter was impacted by higher obsolescence. Going forward, we expect product sales gross margins to trend within a range of approximately 48% to 50% depending on product sales mix.
Moving on to operating expenses. Second quarter operating expenses totaled $181 million, compared to $190 million in the prior year. Current quarter restructuring and other charges of $23 million were comprised of $60 million of severance cost and other asset write-offs primarily related to the closure of our Japan operations and $7 million of intellectual property impairment recorded primarily due to uncertainties around how certain that patents fit with our product strategy going forward. Excluding restructuring and other, second quarter operating expenses and operating income margin would have been $158 million and 24% respectively, compared to $182 million and 17% respectively in the prior-year quarter, primarily due to lower bad debt provisions and lower expenses largely related to cost control efforts.
Update on our cost reduction efforts. We continue to move towards our goal of the previously announced $200 million of cost savings when compared to the fourth quarter of 2008. We feel that we're on track to achieve our cost reduction goals as we move throughout 2010 and exit the year. SG&A, excluding bad debt, declined $12 million or 12% to $84 million for the quarter as a result of our continued cost control efforts, including lower legal and compliance fees. We expect quarterly SG&A to be in the run rate of $90 million, $95 million. 
Bad debt provisions has totaled $2 million for the quarter compared to $13 million in the last year's quarter. The bad debt decrease for the quarter primarily stems from fewer specific reserves related to customers which were affected by the economic environment. R&D expense totaled $53 million for the quarter flat compared to the prior quarter. We expect the quarterly R&D run rate in the low $50 million area. Depreciation, amortization within operating expenses totaled $19 million for the quarter, which is flat to the prior year. Total depreciation and amortization, inclusive of that included in the game ops, was $58 million for the quarter, down from $69 million in the prior quarter. The decline in total depreciation and amortization was primarily due to lower depreciation in our domestic MegaJackpots business and our Mexico lease operations. Please note that some of this will come back as we refresh our installed base of assets. 
Other income and expense net in the second quarter was a net expense of $22 million, compared to $19 million in the prior-year quarter. The change was mostly due to increased borrowing cost, partially offset by less foreign exchange loss. Additional convertible debt amortization acquired under our accounting guidance, adopted retrospectively at the beginning of the fiscal year, increased interest expense by $7 million in the quarter and $4 million in the prior-year period. In addition, we expect non-cash interest of approximately $30 million, $19 million after tax or $0.06 per diluted share for fiscal 2010 and approximately $35 million, $22 million after tax or $0.08 per diluted share for fiscal 2009 as restated, including repurchased gains of $5 million.
Moving on to the tax rate. Our tax rate came in at 50% in the second quarter versus 34% in the prior-year quarter. The tax rate during the quarter was impacted due to significant one-time items, i.e. largely the intellectual property impairment and the impairment charges taken in Japan. The current quarter tax rate, excluding this one-time items was approximately 38%. Going forward, we expect our quarterly tax rate to trend at approximately 37% to 39% before discreet items. However, we may experience volatility in our quarterly tax rate due to the impact of 1048 and quarterly discrete items including the expected closure of various audit cycles.
Moving on to the balance sheet. Cash and equivalents and short-term investments, inclusive of restricted amounts, totaled $259 million at March 31, 2010, compared to $247 million at September 30, 2009. Contractual debt obligations totaled $2 billion with $1.2 billion available under our line of credit. It is important to note that these options of new accounting rules for convertible debt, which I mentioned earlier, decreased our book debt by approximately $138 million at March 31, 2010, and $155 million at September 30, 2009. This amount is beyond amortized discount related to the implied value of the equity options in our converts, which was recorded in equity. For purpose of bank covenants, we will continue to use contractual debt obligations which totaled $2 billion as of March 31, a decrease of $142 million compared to September 30, 2009.
Our 3.25% convertible notes and warrants were excluded from the diluted shares outstanding for the period ended March 31, because the conversion price and the exercise price exceeded the average market price of our common stock.
On the balance sheet, we made a lot of progress with our working capital ratios and conversion of working capital of free cash flow. Working capital totaled $647 million at March 31, compared to $609 million at September 30. Average days sales outstanding excluding receivables from our notes and contracts was 54 days, down from 58 days as of September 30. Inventory turns averaged 3.7x up from 3x at September 30.
For the six months ended March 31, IGT generated $277 million in cash flow from operations, compared to $206 million for the first six months of last year. During the quarter, we saw a continued improvement in working capital efficiencies such as reduced inventory balance, the lowest it's been in 40 quarters.
For the six months ended March 31, 2010, IGT reported $124 million in free cash flow compared to negative $14 million for the first six months of last year. All of the free cash flow generated in 2010 has been used to pay down debt. Capital expenditures totaled $64 million for the quarter, compared to $53 million in the prior sequential quarter due to higher investments in game ops assets. CapEx is expected to trend in a quarterly range of $65 million to $75 million. Although we continue to come in near the lower end of the range as we more proactively manage our CapEx, is part of our efficiency and cost reduction efforts. 
We understand that the bill, which would have allowed the Alabama voters to decide on a constitutional amendment authorizing bingo, including electronic charitable bingo at the state level, did not pass the Alabama House. Notwithstanding this unfortunate legislative outcome, we believe the electronic charitable bingo terminals at our customers' VictoryLand Country Crossing and Greenetrack are legal. 
Despite our belief, there does exist some risk that the properties will be able to continue operating or will reopen in the case of Country Crossing. We continue to monitor the Alabama charitable market. In the near future, electronic charitable bingo in the state may be impacted by the outcome of several cases pending before the Alabama Supreme Court or from other developments. As of March 31, 2010, we had approximately $85.5 million on development financing notes, $9.2 million on fixed assets and $7.2 million in accounts receivable associated with our customers in Alabama.
That concludes my prepared remarks regarding IGT's second quarter. And I'll now turn the call over to Patti.

headline: International Game Technology, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Pat, and good afternoon, everyone. Thank you very much for taking the time to join us as we discuss our fiscal second quarter.As many of you know, we have been tampering expectations on the state of the market over the past several quarters a
componenttext:
Thank you, Pat, and good afternoon, everyone. Thank you very much for taking the time to join us as we discuss our fiscal second quarter.
As many of you know, we have been tampering expectations on the state of the market over the past several quarters as we await a sustained and meaningful increase in customer spending levels. And similar to most of you, we remain cautiously optimistic about the macro environment but more enthusiastic about several bright spots in certain areas of our business.
In Gaming Operations, overall yields were $51.70 for the quarter, an improvement of 5% sequentially, reflecting a slight increase in play levels. Our MegaJackpots yield improved 11% sequentially, with Sex and the City continuing to perform earning up to $1,260 per day for our customers.
In addition, we have now deployed 149 units of Amazing Race and 93 units of Top Dollar, our latest generation of titles in our Gaming Operations business. At 4,100 shipped units, our North American replacement sales improved 37% from the prior sequential quarter, the sign of market improvement and a testament to the quality of our latest for-sale titles.
We also made progress on several strategic marketing initiatives during the quarter to better respond to the needs of our customers while reinforcing our historical strength, including: The continuation of a program to refresh our market-leading Wheel of Fortune brand; the announcement of a backward integration solution or our Service Window functionality; and a continued production of certain titles for convergence on our 8960 platform. 
Joining us today is Eric Tom, our Executive Vice President of North American Sales and Marketing, who will tell you a bit more about these programs and give you a broader overview of our customer-facing activities.

headline: International Game Technology, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Patti. I'm pleased to talk about this quarter's activity in both games and systems. We believe this activity showcases our innovative talents and maximizes the value propositions to our customers.As Patti mentioned, we are highly focused on l
componenttext:
Thank you, Patti. I'm pleased to talk about this quarter's activity in both games and systems. We believe this activity showcases our innovative talents and maximizes the value propositions to our customers.
As Patti mentioned, we are highly focused on leveraging our historical strength. We continue to refresh our signature brand, Wheel of Fortune. The first title for a new Center Stage game series is Wheel of Fortune Experience, available with both three- and five-reel games. Additionally, we recently unveiled Wheel of Fortune multi-play, which allows players to play up to four concurrent based games. And finally, Wheel of Fortune Secret Spins, a game in which the wheel rotates to reveal an extra multiplier, will be introduced to the market later this year.
Additionally, we continue to focus certain aspects of our product strategy on initiatives designed to maximize our share of those lean customer budgets. There are three examples, first, our previously announced Service Window solution to a legacy 80960 video machine further the company's commitment to providing our customers with cost-effective and flexible solutions for a network quarter floor. Its backward integration solution, which is scheduled to be deployed in fall 2010, allows our customers to satisfy demands for Service Window capabilities in our existing 80960 footprint. Second, so far this year, we released 21 new convergent games for our legacy 8960 spinning reel and video platforms. These games enable our customers to freshen their floors with limited expenditure while reinforcing our existing position in their casino. And third, we continue to experience success with our DynamiX package, which bundles one new AVP slot machine with two 80960 conversion kits, allowing the customer to refresh three machines concurrently.
Through March 31, we sold 4,017 units under this customer-friendly program. I would also like to highlight other important initiatives that we are executing. Patti mentioned our success with Sex and the City, Amazing Race and Top Dollar. And we are excited about the continued improvement in our game operations product portfolio. As of March 31, our backlog for these three teams, plus the recently released Wheel of Fortune Experience stood at 2,153 units.
In the first two quarters of 2010, for our For Sale business, we have released 80 game titles, compared to 30 titles during the same period in 2009. These included an even mix of spinning reel and video slot games. Some of the exiting new titles include, Pirate Bay, Kodiak King and Majestic Sea. We anticipate another 50 to 70 titles to be released through the remainder of this fiscal year. And as of April 19, we have 3,200 games in the backlog. We are now over 13,000 AVP units with MLD in the marketplace, offering 3D games and enabling spinning reels, video slots and poker slots all in one machine.
Now turning to systems. We continue to be encouraged by the performance of our server-based gaming system in Aria. We believe we have met our customers' high expectations with a first system of its kind. During the second quarter, we announced several key Tier One successes, including Casino di Venezia in Italy, Grand Casino in Helsinki, The Orleans and Colusa and Mohawk.
In North America, as of March 31, we are in varying contract stages with two other sbX opportunities and seven other tier I opportunities. Please understand there is no guarantee that we will close all these opportunities. In our Traditional Systems business, we continue to face a challenging new build environment with few additional casino properties scheduled to open in the near term. With that being said, this quarter we have closed three new Advantage customers as of March 31. And as of that date, we are in varying contract stages with five new Advantage customers. Again, no guarantee that we'll close all these opportunities. We are also aggressively focused on marketing sbX to our existing Advantage customers, who are ideal candidate to leverage the power of this new platform.
Now more broadly, we continue to receive positive feedback from our customers for our restructured North American sales organization. Implemented in September of 2009, this change included the addition of strategic account managers, highly trained sales personnel, who manage our largest customers, and our focus on corporate relationships, system and marketing opportunities.
Additionally, we now have each account manager responsible for the entire IGT portfolio. The breadth of which we consider to be a competitive advantage. We also organized our systems, professional services and poker experts to more effectively assist our frontline account managers.
So as we move forward in our sales and marketing strategies, we'll continue to focus on content quality, product innovation and a customer first approach to market. And with that, I will turn it back over to Patti to speak about our broader corporate initiatives and our outlook for the remainder of 2010.

headline: International Game Technology, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Eric. Last quarter, we discussed our measured success. And in light of the continued challenging environment this quarter, I will focus on activity pertinent to those items that are under our control. Our balance sheet metrics continue to impro
componenttext:
Thank you, Eric. Last quarter, we discussed our measured success. And in light of the continued challenging environment this quarter, I will focus on activity pertinent to those items that are under our control. Our balance sheet metrics continue to improve with working capital reduced by $88 million from the prior-year quarter and total contractual debt obligations declining by $80 million sequentially.
We remain extremely focused on free cash flow generation. We continue to actively manage cost in the midst of the challenging environment as evidenced by the decline in operating expense of 13%, excluding restructuring and other charges and a decline in SG&A of 12%, excluding bad debt over the prior-year quarter.
Additionally, we continue to make forward-looking and occasionally difficult capital allocation decisions. We continue to prepare our product and financing strategies for the impending 35,000- to 40,000-units Illinois expansion. We anticipate that the central system provider will be announced shortly with the associated rules and regulations issued thereafter. And we anticipate units to begin shipping in the first quarter of 2011.
We recently announced our decision to exit from the Japanese patent law [ph](47:13) market. And while we are never happy to part with employees, difficult markets require difficult decisions. Looking forward, Gideon Bierer, our Executive Vice President of New Media, continues to establish his organization, an organization that will focus on the emerging opportunities in our industry. While Chris Satchell, our Chief Technology Officer continues to focus on platform improvement, a critical aspect of our future game development efforts. Both Gideon and Chris are implementing initiatives that will have long-term impact on our business. Again, we continue to work tirelessly to improve IGT for our customers, our employees and most importantly, for you, our shareholders.
As I mentioned, we remain cautiously optimistic regarding operator budgets and spending. But the seasonally slow first half of the year behind us, we are looking forward to an increasingly clear view of the industry prospects for the remainder of the fiscal year. As I previously noted, there have been significant changes to our capital structure and certain changes in accounting principles, which impact our current quarter results relative to our prior periods.
We have adjusted our guidance to reflect the rest of the potential loss of revenues associated with units in Alabama. As a result of all these factors, our guidance for 2010 has changed to a range of $0.77 to $0.85 per diluted share. As always, our guidance excludes one-time items. Our guidance also assumes no dilution impact from our convertible notes. 
And with that, we'll open the call for questions.

componenttextpreview: Yes, I think in the yield story, I think the two primary areas where we saw a definite improvement in yields, some of this may have been largely due to -- the last couple of years, seasonality uptick has been in the February, March timeframe for within, I
componenttext: Yes, I think in the yield story, I think the two primary areas where we saw a definite improvement in yields, some of this may have been largely due to -- the last couple of years, seasonality uptick has been in the February, March timeframe for within, I don't know if that's -- because there's pent-up demand after the Christmas holidays and a slow January. But anyway, we've seen that now two years in a row, where we see a nice uptick. But we believe part of that uptick is due to the new products. We've now had Sex and the City in that installed base for a while. Amazing Race and Top Dollar started going out this quarter, so probably weren't as impactful. But also in the Wide Area Progressive business, we saw yields up nicely sequentially, and really without much in the way a new product can get there yet. That will come starting this quarter with Wheel of Fortune Experience, as Eric mentioned.

headline: International Game Technology, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010

componenttext: And we started, I think, Robin, last quarter, to start to see some of the signs of Alabama. So when you look at it sequentially, I mean, it's up sequentially. And the MegaJackpots part of the business, up 11% sequentially. So that will give you a sense, if you look at same-store sales, looking at MegaJackpots quarter-on-quarter, will give you a sense, I think, of the improvement.

headline: International Game Technology, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Generally, Robin, I'd say when we introduce a game, from introduction to where we're pretty completely rolled out, at least through the bulk of it, it usually takes about six months, in the normal course. And I think, that's about what we're seeing. We're
componenttext: Generally, Robin, I'd say when we introduce a game, from introduction to where we're pretty completely rolled out, at least through the bulk of it, it usually takes about six months, in the normal course. And I think, that's about what we're seeing. We're continually trying to accelerate that wherever we can. So there had been a lot of initiatives between manufacturing and the field service organization to accelerate that wherever we can. But it is a kind of a function of how many people do you have.

headline: International Game Technology, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. And I think, a couple of things, Robin, contribute to a price. First, is the customer's desired delivery date. And the second, in many cases, is the jurisdictional approvement [approval]. So currently, I think, Sex and the City is an example. It's ap
componenttext: Yes. And I think, a couple of things, Robin, contribute to a price. First, is the customer's desired delivery date. And the second, in many cases, is the jurisdictional approvement [approval]. So currently, I think, Sex and the City is an example. It's approved in about 17 jurisdictions, so some of the backlog is waiting for jurisdictional approvement [approval] to move out. Some of it's waiting for the customer delivery date to be determined.

headline: International Game Technology, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: And I'll add in, consistent with our philosophy of managing cash where we can influence the shortening of that install cycle we do, we just assign three people to specifically coordinate with customers to decrease the time to install and to actually sched
componenttext: And I'll add in, consistent with our philosophy of managing cash where we can influence the shortening of that install cycle we do, we just assign three people to specifically coordinate with customers to decrease the time to install and to actually schedule, which used to run three to four weeks and we're trying narrow down to one to two weeks. So simple things like that are all helping the process.

componenttext: From the time it was introduced. So if you look at that backlog, the smallest piece of that backlog are the tail-end of the units that were demand for Sex and the City, because it was the first introduced. The most recent game was Top Dollar, which just got introduced here within, say, the last month. And then, as we say, we'll be introducing now, and in fact, I think the first units had just started going on certain of the Native American floors for Wheel of Fortune experience. So you'll hopefully be able to see that live in the casino with people playing it here, one of these days.

headline: International Game Technology, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Steven Kent. [Goldman Sachs]
componenttext: And our next question comes from Steven Kent. [Goldman Sachs]

headline: International Game Technology, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Eric or Patti, maybe you could just broadly tell us what your customers are saying out there, because I guess, I'm struggling with some level of replacement sales, how much they're really interested in replacing machines, and sort of are the gating issues
componenttext: Eric or Patti, maybe you could just broadly tell us what your customers are saying out there, because I guess, I'm struggling with some level of replacement sales, how much they're really interested in replacing machines, and sort of are the gating issues that are holding them back. And what would make them accelerate or decelerate their replacement sales. And since you, throughout in the field, a lot of -- I thought it would be good to hear from you. Separately, on the incentives, it sounds like you are giving a few more incentives to get people to buy machines. And given how many great machines you have out there, better product in a couple of years, what's the rationale for doing that?

headline: International Game Technology, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Let me talk first about my views of customer sentiment and then I'll let Eric add his as well. I mean, I think, I mean, my view and my decisions with customers is that they see the value in the new product. They see the value in the MLD product. They see
componenttext: Let me talk first about my views of customer sentiment and then I'll let Eric add his as well. I mean, I think, I mean, my view and my decisions with customers is that they see the value in the new product. They see the value in the MLD product. They see a need to refresh their floors. I think, the biggest obstacle is their capital budgets. I mean, they are under the same pressure we're all under, to manage their returns to their shareholders. And so it's really in my mind, just restricted capital budget. And I think, I indicated before, Steve, when we talked, there's a lot more planning going on right now than there is buying. But I think, when the capital budgets come in, you'll see a bit more buying moving up. So anything you may want to add?

headline: International Game Technology, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: I have a similar conversation with customers along those lines. They want to refresh their floors, we've missed the whole cycle. They see that their floors need that re-investment. But capital budget's being controlled so tightly. They just don't have the
componenttext:
I have a similar conversation with customers along those lines. They want to refresh their floors, we've missed the whole cycle. They see that their floors need that re-investment. But capital budget's being controlled so tightly. They just don't have the opportunity. With that, we really focused on how we can facilitate the refreshener of floors and minimize the capital budget. So one of the reasons why the dynamics package made sense to us and actually turned out to be very successful, is that it combines the refreshing of two older games, which are susceptible to replacement because they're older, they're an older theme. At the same time, leveraging the minimal capital budget that you have to buy in the next-generation platform. So it's kind of win-win investment in the future, but you solidify the past. And it made a lot of sense because, these 8,960 game themes that we put out to convergent themes.
don't cost very much, I mean, $500 a piece to a $1,000 total. The other area that we're focused on, because the capital budgets are so limited, is placing new MegaJackpot themes on the floor, because it's capitalist to the customer, it refreshes the floor that's in need of refreshing. And there's a lot of energy behind the new labels. So everybody seems to be excited about that, and we're having a good run at it [indiscernible] (1:00:28).

headline: International Game Technology, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: And I think, Steve, just digging to your second question, which I think, is just as important to drive home and that is the obstacle between where we are in increased volume has very little to do with game performance. It's about capital budgets. So what
componenttext: And I think, Steve, just digging to your second question, which I think, is just as important to drive home and that is the obstacle between where we are in increased volume has very little to do with game performance. It's about capital budgets. So what we have to do is help our customer address their biggest strategic issues. So we see the dynamics package as strategic. It does protect our installed base and protect our position on the floor, at a point in time when the replacement environment is at such low levels. So we see it as a strategic, not a direct -- that, combined with our product performance, on the MLD product in particular, we think is very strategic for the market.

headline: International Game Technology, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010

componenttext: And our next question comes from Steve Wieczynski. [Stifel, Nicolaus]

headline: International Game Technology, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: You talked a little bit about Illinois. But can you give us an update in terms of Italy, in terms of what you think, in terms of the size of the market and timing?
componenttext: You talked a little bit about Illinois. But can you give us an update in terms of Italy, in terms of what you think, in terms of the size of the market and timing?

headline: International Game Technology, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Italy, I think, the size of the market, our view, hasn't really changed. Timing, I think, has moved out. I think if you talk to everybody involved there, including the operators themselves, they'll tell you that it's going slower than they thought. And th
componenttext: Italy, I think, the size of the market, our view, hasn't really changed. Timing, I think, has moved out. I think if you talk to everybody involved there, including the operators themselves, they'll tell you that it's going slower than they thought. And the reason for that is there's not one consistent system solution being offered there. And invariably, it's one person providing maybe the game system, but they have to interface to someone else's monitoring system. So there's a fair amount of engineering work that happen to go on, on the part of everybody that's supplying there. For us, I don't know, if we have much. I think, we announced two deals around the time of the London show that were both done by our U.K. subsidiary. I don't know if we have anything yet today to talk about out of the European operation that caters toward the more casino-oriented product. And so probably, later this year, late part of the summer, maybe before the end of the calendar year, you might see some shipments starting to go in there.

headline: International Game Technology, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: And then in terms of the guidance, I just want to make sure I got this right, you took the top end down by $0.02. Was that fully a function of just Alabama?
componenttext: And then in terms of the guidance, I just want to make sure I got this right, you took the top end down by $0.02. Was that fully a function of just Alabama?

headline: International Game Technology, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's really baking in the rest of revenue to Alabama that we think is becoming -- first of all, a bit difficult for us to control from a timing perspective. It's, for the most part, in the hands of the politicians and the attorneys at the state. And
componenttext: Yes, it's really baking in the rest of revenue to Alabama that we think is becoming -- first of all, a bit difficult for us to control from a timing perspective. It's, for the most part, in the hands of the politicians and the attorneys at the state. And so we're doing everything we can, but our influence there is not as great as we would like for it to be. So we decided we would bake in that risk in the guidance just to make certain that you all were seeing what we're seeing.

headline: International Game Technology, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: I guess, just a follow-up on the ASPs one last time. Purchases is now less about game performance, it's more about capital budget. So if others do follow on bundling deals and theses types of arrangements, does that become more of a slippery slope? Or is
componenttext: I guess, just a follow-up on the ASPs one last time. Purchases is now less about game performance, it's more about capital budget. So if others do follow on bundling deals and theses types of arrangements, does that become more of a slippery slope? Or is this something -- is there something you can give us that saw us [ph](1:04:16) that this is kind of the bottom run rate we should be seeing on ASP?

headline: International Game Technology, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: I'll give you my comments and Pat, you add yours. I think the bundling again, the bundling and packaging is focused on splitting the activity between converting the old installed base and selling new machines. And as we move out of this level of replaceme
componenttext: I'll give you my comments and Pat, you add yours. I think the bundling again, the bundling and packaging is focused on splitting the activity between converting the old installed base and selling new machines. And as we move out of this level of replacement cycle into the next level replacement cycle where customers become less focused on refreshing the old machines and they become more focused on replacing them, then the dynamics products kind of disappears for us. So if you look at the ASP on a stand-alone product, less the discount, looking back on the convergence, you still find the same levels of ASPs that we've been enjoying. But you're getting the discounts of a convergent package. So as they move away from combining convergence with new purchases, you'll find the ASPs will reflect that.

headline: International Game Technology, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: And I think, David, in general, if you talk to casino operators, which you will do, you can just tell the overall level of demand is much lower than it otherwise might be, because of, at this point, the capital. I think, for us, our products are getting b
componenttext: And I think, David, in general, if you talk to casino operators, which you will do, you can just tell the overall level of demand is much lower than it otherwise might be, because of, at this point, the capital. I think, for us, our products are getting better and therefore, the game performances sway more of that business our way. But it's still -- you have to assume a pretty competitive environment, because you have everybody buying for a lower level of demand.

headline: International Game Technology, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: And in many cases, you're not competing with, are they going to purchase from us or someone else, but are they going to purchase or not purchase. And that's really the decision we need to input.
componenttext: And in many cases, you're not competing with, are they going to purchase from us or someone else, but are they going to purchase or not purchase. And that's really the decision we need to input.

headline: International Game Technology, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: And then also on the -- is there some sort of forecasting, Pat, you can give us for ship not recognized for future quarters? There was some benefit there and it makes it a little bit tougher to model going forward. In fact, it keeps moving around, or is t
componenttext: And then also on the -- is there some sort of forecasting, Pat, you can give us for ship not recognized for future quarters? There was some benefit there and it makes it a little bit tougher to model going forward. In fact, it keeps moving around, or is that going to be a steady number that we can  kind of...

headline: International Game Technology, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: I think, it's going to become more steady and here's why, in Q1, we're able to early adopt the renewed two new EITF, that come out, both dealing with revenue recognition. And as you saw this quarter, it made it easier for us to bifurcate the hardware from
componenttext: I think, it's going to become more steady and here's why, in Q1, we're able to early adopt the renewed two new EITF, that come out, both dealing with revenue recognition. And as you saw this quarter, it made it easier for us to bifurcate the hardware from the software, so that we're not happened defer revenue on machines where there really is value earlier than when, maybe a system, for example, are the most complicated ones. And then we're just getting better about making sure that the accounting folks are joined at the hip with the legal folks and the sales folks as we're constructing deals, rather than lighting the deals, we get put together and then we get stuck, having to live with whatever the accounting treatment is.

headline: International Game Technology, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Just a question for you, Patti. You brought in a lot of non-gaming people into the organization over the course of last year. How is that total transformation at IGT tracking?
componenttext: Just a question for you, Patti. You brought in a lot of non-gaming people into the organization over the course of last year. How is that total transformation at IGT tracking?

headline: International Game Technology, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: I mean, we have brought a lot of folks that don't have wager-based gaming experience. Chris Satchell is bringing the very long history in gaming for Microsoft to the Company. So when you look at the Senior Management team, it's kind of split half and half
componenttext: I mean, we have brought a lot of folks that don't have wager-based gaming experience. Chris Satchell is bringing the very long history in gaming for Microsoft to the Company. So when you look at the Senior Management team, it's kind of split half and half. We have folks who have in the industry a very long time and we have some new thinkers in the business. But I think, with the right balance, where the areas we're gaining experience is very important from a product development perspective, from a technology-investment perspective, from the intellectual property creation perspective. We have Eric towards the side of protecting that gaming legacy, and in the areas of legal and compliance, as with sales and new media obviously, we've been less so. So culturally, going well so far. I think, again, we're really relying on both sides to do what we need them to do, like the new eyes to really push and challenge why are we doing things this way. And those legacy executives, including all the legacy employees of IGT, to really challenge and help understand why we do things certain way. But I think, what we're finding, as we're working through that, is we're moving our decisions to the middle, to a balance of input from both sides of that equation. So I would say, at this point, it's going well. We're starting to do some things differently. Now we've invested in marketing for really the first time in this company's history. And when Eric has created the marketing organization, the things about, the four keys at marketing, in product, in placement, promotion and price and bundling and packaging and our brand, in ways that we haven't been thinking about it. We think about our routes to market differently than we've thought about them before. And I would say that some of our competitors have done a better job than we have over the last several years, at bringing in new thinking that challenges the status quo. And we're at a point in -- and not only our company, but in this industry, where we just need to do more of that. So I would say at this point, I would give it a high marks. And we'll see who wears down whom first.

headline: International Game Technology, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: And if we look at the reconfiguration you've done at the design studios, are all of those studios now equally producing products? Or is it one or two studios is producing more products than the rest, and how long some of those other studios are pushing mo
componenttext: And if we look at the reconfiguration you've done at the design studios, are all of those studios now equally producing products? Or is it one or two studios is producing more products than the rest, and how long some of those other studios are pushing more product out into the field?

headline: International Game Technology, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: We have, for all intents and purposes, [indiscernible] (1:10:32) there to be five studios today. We have a system studio and then we have our four Game Studios. And we think less about quantity, coming out of each of the two units, because they each play
componenttext: We have, for all intents and purposes, [indiscernible] (1:10:32) there to be five studios today. We have a system studio and then we have our four Game Studios. And we think less about quantity, coming out of each of the two units, because they each play a different role. That's a studio that is responsible for our video poker product, is less about quantity, frankly. And when you think about the Game Ops business, that's really about return on capital and we have those folks focused on the performance of their games against the capital that IGT strands at the marketplace. So we don't think about it as much as quantity, frankly, as we think about each role that the relevant each studio plays in the market. Now, I will say, as always in every quarter, you're going to have studios that play stronger than others, and we have that at this particular time. But that's based on the needs of the business, less than the talent of the workforce. So when the needs of the business shift, you do have to widen and push studious differently. And so we're doing that. So I would say, it will never be equal because studios are studios and their creative people. So we'll never be equal. But I think, we had each studio playing the role that the company has defined for them to play. Eric, do you have anything to add to that?

headline: International Game Technology, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: I think, it does trend -- we've actually put a lot of discipline in the product management function, in defining the type of games, we believe, the marketplace is looking for. And there's always a -- it depends upon time or the cycles in the marketplace,
componenttext: I think, it does trend -- we've actually put a lot of discipline in the product management function, in defining the type of games, we believe, the marketplace is looking for. And there's always a -- it depends upon time or the cycles in the marketplace, gaps in our product portfolio. I think, in the past, we might have developed games based on probably a less-disciplined manner. So I think that, as Patti mentioned, as we define different requirements, different studious to play a more significant role for those requirements. But a much more sophisticated approach to game development, which we are finding to be very productive and probably more effective, as we launch these products in the market.

headline: International Game Technology, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: If the replacement cycle comes back next year, as many expect, do you think that sales of convergent kits may correspondingly decrease while set that [ph] (1:12:46)?
componenttext: If the replacement cycle comes back next year, as many expect, do you think that sales of convergent kits may correspondingly decrease while set that [ph] (1:12:46)?

headline: International Game Technology, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: On sales convergent kits, possibly into that 8,960 platform. But keep you have to keep in mind that we're now starting to get a fair number of AVPs, some of which are getting to be rather elongated themselves, that are better able to handle some of the ne
componenttext: On sales convergent kits, possibly into that 8,960 platform. But keep you have to keep in mind that we're now starting to get a fair number of AVPs, some of which are getting to be rather elongated themselves, that are better able to handle some of the new games coming down the line. So it's possible, Cameron. I think, probably less so international. I think, international tends to lag the domestic market a little bit.

headline: International Game Technology, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: I think, the other thing, Cameron, as you look forward into 2011, 2012 when you think about convergence, the notion of a convergence for IGT will change pretty dramatically, from what today is kind of a hardware, firmware, software change, to over time be
componenttext: I think, the other thing, Cameron, as you look forward into 2011, 2012 when you think about convergence, the notion of a convergence for IGT will change pretty dramatically, from what today is kind of a hardware, firmware, software change, to over time being very software configurable. So we will think about convergence differently, going forward than we think about them today, as we go into converging, not only into our Game Ops business, but into some of the higher-end AVP boxes. We'll be more of a software convergence than a hardware firmware convergence.

componenttext: I think, that's the goal. On your first question, Todd, I don't know -- we've hadn't known if there's a hard date. And as far as we know, everybody is working towards that goal. But without a real hard stop date as to when is that going to be in the end of June, or the end of September, I don't know is, we can really remark.
