headline: International Game Technology, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Liza. Good afternoon, everyone, and welcome to IGT's Fourth Quarter and Fiscal Year 2010 Earnings Conference Call. On the call with me today is Patti Hart, President and CEO; Pat Cavanaugh, CFO; and Eric Tom, COO.Before beginning, we'd like t
componenttext:
Thank you, Liza. Good afternoon, everyone, and welcome to IGT's Fourth Quarter and Fiscal Year 2010 Earnings Conference Call. On the call with me today is Patti Hart, President and CEO; Pat Cavanaugh, CFO; and Eric Tom, COO.
Before beginning, we'd like to remind listeners our discussion reflects management's views based on the business environment as of today, November 9, 2010, and will include forward-looking statements, including forecast of future performance and estimates of amounts not yet determinable, the potential for growth of existing and the opening of new jurisdictions for our products, play levels for our installed base of recurring revenue gains, as well as our future prospects and proposed new products, services, developments or business strategies.
We do not intend and undertake no obligation to update our forward-looking statements to reflect future events or circumstances. Actual results may differ materially. Additional information about factors which could potentially impact our financial results is included in today's press release and our filings with the SEC, including our most recent annual report on Form 10-K, and our quarterly reports on Form 10-Q filed during fiscal 2010.
During this call, we may discuss certain non-GAAP financial measures including adjusted earnings per share, adjusted operating expenses, adjusted operating margin, adjusted EBITDA and free cash flow. In our press release, which is posted in our website, www.igt.com, you will find additional disclosures regarding any non-GAAP measures, including reconciliations of these measures with comparable GAAP measures. 
With that in mind, I'll turn the call over to Patti.

headline: International Game Technology, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Matt, and good afternoon, everyone. In fiscal year 2010, we continued to have relatively strong financial performance in an economy that remains weakened. More importantly, we've set the company on a course to achieve greater financial and operati
componenttext:
Thanks, Matt, and good afternoon, everyone. In fiscal year 2010, we continued to have relatively strong financial performance in an economy that remains weakened. More importantly, we've set the company on a course to achieve greater financial and operational performance in the future. 
Our 2010 financial achievements include growing our international revenues by 21% to $559 million, increasing our adjusted operating margin by 200 basis points to 25% and reducing our debt obligation by over $400 million. 
Despite the challenging macro environment, our revenues were nearly $2 billion and we produced over $770 million of adjusted EBITDA, demonstrating our significant cash flow generation capabilities. We also improved our leverage ratio, increased our inventory turns and accomplished all of this with much lower overhead. We are intent on driving higher returns for our stakeholders. 
Meanwhile, many of our customers are improving their financial position, which gives them the opportunity to increase investment in their slot floors. This is a very important step in getting our industry back on a growth track. 
The bottom line results of these achievements are adjusted EPS of $0.85 for the year at the upper end of our latest guidance. It also represents my team's intense focus on making IGT the leanest, most competitive organization that it can be. As I've said before, driving constant improvement at IGT is a short-, medium- and long-term theme for me and my management team. I am proud of our 2010 financial results, and our company’s is focused on making the coming quarters and years even better. 
Personally, I have been spending a lot of time with our customers, both domestically and internationally. These meetings solidify my faith that IGT is an industry leader and that we are doing the right things. That said, I am still cautiously optimistic about the coming year. While it appears that the visitation numbers are stabilizing, it is still too early to call the bottom. We need to see a marked improvement in the economy in the form of more jobs, higher consumer confidence and disposable income before we can expect to see a return to healthy top line growth in our industry.  Internationally, we are enthusiastic about our growing business and the potential we see in new jurisdictions. 
Finally, 2010 essentially completed my transition into the CEO role with IGT, and my leadership team is fully embedded into the business. Our long-term global strategies are now in place, and every employee has a clear understanding of our goals.  Fiscal 2011 is shaping up to be a rewarding year as we start seeing the results of our well-planned strategy. 
I will now ask Pat to share with you some of the financial details for both the fourth quarter and the fiscal year. Pat?

headline: International Game Technology, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Patti, and good afternoon, everyone. This afternoon, IGT reported its results for the fourth quarter and the fiscal year 2010. GAAP net income from continuing ops came in for the fourth quarter at $26 million or $0.09 per share, inclusive of non
componenttext:
Thanks, Patti, and good afternoon, everyone. This afternoon, IGT reported its results for the fourth quarter and the fiscal year 2010. 
GAAP net income from continuing ops came in for the fourth quarter at $26 million or $0.09 per share, inclusive of noncash charges of $27 million after tax or $0.09 per share. This compares a net loss of $10 million or $0.04 a share in the previous fourth quarter, last year's fourth quarter. For the year, GAAP net income from continuing ops is $224 million or $0.75 per share, compared to $153 million or $0.52 per share last year, an increase of over 40%. 
Both the fourth quarter and fiscal year were affected by a number of noncash items, the details of which are broken out in our earnings release which went out earlier today. Our adjusted EPS was $0.85 for the year and $0.18 for the fourth quarter, both near the top end of our previous guidance. 
We are particularly pleased with our adjusted operating margin that came in at 25% this year versus 23% last year, perhaps one of the best in the supplier space. Our consolidated revenues for the fourth quarter were $496 million, of which 54% were generated from our Gaming Ops business and the remainder from product sales. For the year, our revenues were $2 billion, 55% from Gaming Ops and the rest from product sales. 
Consolidated gross profit increased 100 basis points to 56% and total $1.1 billion for the year. Our Gaming Operations continued to feel the impact of challenging economic conditions, although we are encouraged by continued stabilization in yields. 
Gaming Ops revenues were $268 million in the fourth quarter, which is down 3% sequentially and 5% year-over-year. Gross margins decreased 200 basis points to 58% for the quarter, primarily due to fixed costs spread over a smaller installed base. 
We're in an average of $50.86 per unit, per day, which is up slightly compared to last year's fourth quarter. The splendid yield is an average of the various components of our broadened global installed base. Our Game ops yield range from $10 to $15 per day in some of the lower-yielding markets, such as racinos and in some of our international markets, to more than $100 today in some of our MegaJackpots units. 
On an important side note, our international installed base is now at 16,000 machines. If we look at that on a stand-alone basis, this would make it the third-largest installed base in the industry. 
For the year, Gaming Operations revenues were $1.1 billion compared to prior year revenues of $1.2 billion. And gross margins increased 200 basis points to 60% compared to 58% in the prior year. 
IGT's installed base into the fourth quarter of 57,000 units, down 4,300 units over the prior year, largely attributable to the closure or certain charitable bingo facilities in Alabama. Approximately 82% of our installed base is comprised of variable fee games that are in the percentage of machine play levels rather than a fixed daily fees. 
Moving on to product sales. Product sales revenues totaled $228 million for the quarter, compared to $230 million in the fourth quarter of last year. For FY '10, product sales revenues were $886 million compared to $925 million in the prior year. Both periods were affected by fewer new openings in North America. Worldwide, we recognized and shipped 11,000 machines during the quarter, down from the prior year of 11,300. 
In this fiscal year, IGT recognized 42,200 machines, down from 49,700 machines last year. The units shipped but not yet recognized, please see the supporting data at the back of the press release. 
International product sales revenue totaled $116 million for the quarter on volumes 7,700 units, compared to $102 million and 7,100 units in the prior year quarter. For the fiscal year, International product sales revenue was $391 million, up from $307 million in the prior year, while units recognized for the year were 24,600, up from 23,900 in the previous year. The increase in revenues is primarily due to an increase in shipments into higher revenue jurisdictions and some favorable foreign currency exchange. 
Worldwide non-machine revenues mainly from sales of systems conversions and property fees came in at $89 million for the quarter with 39% of total product sales compared to $98 million and 43% of the product sales in the prior-year quarter. For the year, non-machine revenues were $329 million or 37% of total product sales, down from $346 million and 37% of product sales in the previous year. 
Product sales gross margins were 53% for the quarter, up 100 basis points for the quarter and were 52% for the year, again, up 100 basis points from the previous fiscal year. Domestic new and expansion units shipped but not recognized totaled 1,700 end of quarter, up 800 sequentially due to shipments related to Cosmopolitan and First Council in Oklahoma and the opening of SugarHouse. 
Moving on to operating expenses and others. Fourth quarter operating expense has decreased to $174 million or 35% of revenues, compared to $257 million or 50% of revenues in the prior-year quarter. 
For the full year, operating expenses decreased to $687 million or 35% of revenue, compared to $810 million or 39% of revenue in fiscal 2009. Quarterly adjusted operating expenses decreased slightly to $164 million in the prior-year quarter.  For the full year, adjusted operating expenses decreased 7% to $615 million or 31% of revenues. 
Adjusted non-GAAP operating expenses as reconciled in a supplemental schedule at the end of our press release exclude noncash impairments and losses on other assets, restructuring and debt refinancing costs and bad debt provisions. 
Moving into 2011. We may see SG&A stay about flat on a total dollar basis when compared to the full year 2010 as we invest in the people and processes necessary to take advantage of the expected industry turnaround and new business opportunities. 
SG&A for the fourth quarter was up sequentially but down year-on-year as we recognize certain year-end items and ramped up for this year's G2E and a large amount of new products that we'll be showing. 
R&D expenditures totaled $53 million for the quarter, an increase of $1 million from the prior year. For the year, our investment in R&D was $200 million, down 2% over 2009. We expect R&D to be about flat to up slightly for fiscal 2011. 
Moving on to the balance sheet. Cash equivalents and short-term investments, inclusive of restricted amounts, totaled $249 million at September 30, 2010, compared to $247 million at the end of last year. Contractual debt obligations totaled $1.8 billion at September 30 this year, compared to $2.2 billion last year. 
The available capacity on our $1.5 billion revolver totaled $1.4 billion as of the end of this year.  During this year, we've reduced our debt obligations by over $400 million and improved our leverage ratio significantly. We went from 3.3x levered at the end of last year to 2.4x as we exited this fiscal year. 
For the year, we generated $280 million in free cash flow, up from $169 million last year. We also increased our return on invested capital and anticipate further improvement as we move forward. 
That concludes my prepared remarks regarding IGT's quarter and fiscal year. Thanks for your time and attention. I'll turn it back to Patti.

headline: International Game Technology, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Pat. We will continue to strive to improve our financial performance and leverage our industry-leading free cash flow. In the coming year, we will, however, also increase our focus on many important areas. First, we will plan to further reduce o
componenttext:
Thanks, Pat. We will continue to strive to improve our financial performance and leverage our industry-leading free cash flow. In the coming year, we will, however, also increase our focus on many important areas. 
First, we will plan to further reduce our reliance on the North American replacement cycle by taking advantage of our diverse global revenue sources . We expect to begin to see improvement in our Gaming Operations yield. We believe we have the most exciting titles, both on the floor and in our pipeline, and I cannot wait for the world to see some of the best games IGT has ever introduced at G2E this year. We are planning for an increased adoption of our improved systems products and heightened returns on our vast intellectual property portfolio. 
Next, we will continue to expand our far-reaching international presence through both the jurisdictional expansion and market share growth. We will maintain our urgency as it relates to returns on our international invested capital. In the last three years, our international revenues, excluding Japan's discontinued operations, have increased from 20% of total revenues to 28% this year. 
Third, we will continue to find ways to drive our improving profitability and margins even higher.  We carefully monitor every dollar we spend and are continuously looking for ways to minimize SG&A. Our research and development budget is as focused as ever before. We will develop games our customers are demanding and products they value. 
Finally, we are planning to accelerate our growth in the Online and Mobile business. We have attracted some of the best talent available to prepare us for broader participation in the interactive gaming space. We believe that it is inevitable that gaming will become widespread in the developed nations of the world in LAN-based, online and mobile application. We will strive to be the leader in this fast-growing business and to help our customers thrive in the new digital arena. Again, fiscal 2011 will be an exciting year at IGT, much of the change in planning is behind us. Now it is time for all of us to benefit from the returns on our focused activities. 
Eric Tom, our Chief Operating Officer, will now take you through the period specifics on how we plan to achieve these goals. Eric?

headline: International Game Technology, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Patti. We have in place the specific plan and measurement points to meet and exceed our 2011 strategy that Patti has outlined. Let me share with you some of the specifics. First, we expect to see improved financial results from our MegaJackpo
componenttext:
Thank you, Patti. We have in place the specific plan and measurement points to meet and exceed our 2011 strategy that Patti has outlined. Let me share with you some of the specifics. 
First, we expect to see improved financial results from our MegaJackpot business through new player-centric products that are player tested for usability and entertainment value before they are released to the floors. Through new processes, we're quickly incorporating customer feedback and suggestions into our products. We utilize this immediate feedback to better facilitate our sales training, increase the success of future product launches and reduce our stranded capital. We're strengthening our marketing capabilities and increasing our business segmentation efforts. We'll bring new games more quickly and entice and excite both today's slot players and future generations of slot players. For example, our Center Stage product delivers big screen thrills for our players. It is the most exciting platform yet, giving operators the flexibility to simply download new content without having to replace hardware. It is not only a powerful and magnetic presence on the casino floor, but for our shareholders, it represents a reusable platform that provides IGT a new improved set of economics for our Gaming Operations business. It keeps our machines in place longer, reduces turnover and dramatically increases our returns. For the players, they love the multi-way interactive game play, enticing bonus features and incredible sound chairs and huge graphics screens. 
In our core business, we have an unmatched library of video and spinning reel slots. In fiscal year 2010, alone, we released well over 100 new games, more than any other manufacturer. This includes nearly 30 new games on our 8960 box that enables our customers to refresh their floors in this tough economic times. 
We released the number one performing penny video slot, Siberian Storm, that has an innovative interface with over 720 ways to win. We also released Three Kings, the industry's first three-game progressive in the for sale slot segment. It is outperforming our expectations and the competition. 
Our new Reel Edge Series gives players for the first time, control to stop the reels, create wins and use a joystick to control the outcome of the bonuses in the top box. This gives the younger demographic the sense of playing a skill-based game that we believe is much more appealing to them than the traditional slot machine. 
Additionally, we have introduced 3D action with an unmatched gaming experience that makes a game play even more thrilling. For the evolving spinning reel player, our 3D spinning reel games look, feel and sound just like their mechanical counterparts. We refer to this as, the shake, wobble and bounce effect. 
To market all of these games, we have developed an activity-based selling culture in our sales organization. And we are confident that we will drive better results and more satisfied operators. 
While I'm at it, I'm going to talk a little bit about our Video Poker business. IGT is the leading seller of video poker products in the United States for a variety of reasons, not the least of which is our strong intellectual property. 
Moreover, we also believe that we know the customer better than anybody and that our incredible recurring cash flows allow us to be in a great position to maintain our industry leadership. We build many new layers on top of our foundation of patents, and we continue to innovate the product line, which will help us maintain our leadership into the foreseeable future. 
In sum, as we move forward with our global product strategy, we'll continue to focus on core content and leverage our talented pool of game design resources and extensive IT portfolio. 
In our Systems business, we're improving our offering from top to bottom. We have incorporated customer feedback into our next generation of sbX that will increase interoperability with other game developers. We'll allow for intelligent and realtime bonusing that drives increased player loyalty and incremental play. 
For example, we developed an app called W2G. This app allows the player to electronically receive a W2G text form instantly and gets them back to playing. This improves the operators economics and return on investments. This new open-network approach is driving our customers and outside content developers to create applications for our systems that allow for highly customized experiences that boost returns for everyone. We think this really shows the promise of sbX beyond downloading config and the powerful potential of networking slot machines with a flexible slot floor. 
We are eagerly anticipating the upcoming December 15 opening of The Cosmopolitan of Las Vegas. IGT will provide them with a multi-product and system solution, including sbX, 55% of their games, inclusive of 4% MegaJackpots plus an entire suite of Advantage system products. The casino floor will feature a GSA-compliant server-based network, which incorporates the award-winning player focused Service Window, sbX Floor Manager, Media Manager and access to IGT's game library. 
The debut of several applications that will differentiate this next-generation slot floor include an integrated enterprise rating capability that would allow Cosmo to understand the complete value of a customer across the entire resort and to reward patrons based on their particular total spend. 
Additionally, Cosmo will be enabled with an integrated analytical tool that will break down game performance by pay tables versus the generic total box data only available today on integrated systems. 
During the fourth quarter, we have several key Tier One and full sbX successes, including the signing of six new sbX and Tier One customers. The installation of Tier One at three domestic locations and a full sbX installation at two international locations. 
In North America, as of September 30, we are currently in varying contract stages with four sbX opportunities combined with Advantage systems and 27 Tier One opportunities. Please understand that these are only opportunities and there is no guarantee that we will close any of these opportunities. 
Midterm elections were held last week and we feel that the outcome of these elections will benefit us both in the near and long term. In Maryland, voters approved questioning which allows for zoning of a 4,750 VLT slot casino next to Arundel Mills Mall. 
In Alabama, governor-elect Bentley [Robert Bentley], has announced that he'll follow through on his campaign promise to suspend Governor Riley's [Robert Riley] antigambling task force, and instead work with the new attorney general to ensure proper enforcement of the state's gambling statutes. Although the situation remains uncertain, there is a possibility that electronic bingo locations could be allowed to reopen if their machines are checked and approved by proper legal authority. 
With the re-election of Governor Quinn [Pat Quinn] in Illinois, we expect the implementation of the BFT [ph] fealty program to continue. We also feel that the progress towards legalization in Massachusetts will resume next year regardless of their election outcomes. And we expect deliberate progress on other possible new jurisdictions. 
We're committed to developing games that meet our international customers' expectations and exceed the demands of specific regions players, while also reducing cost in inventories and driving higher returns. 
Mexico is a good example of our success in the international markets. We developed an early presence in Class II marketplace with 7,200 machines that provided us a foothold for the eventual conversion to Class III machines. We currently have 7,200 Class III machines in Mexico, all of which, 6,200 are revenue share placements. We have a total of 3,000 AVPs in Mexico with a win-per-unit range of $70 to $140 as compared to our win per unit for Class II machines which was $56. 
I'm energized about this year and beyond for IGT. As Patti mentioned, we spent much of the last year or so developing our strong long-term strategy. It is now time to execute and see the results. 
With that, I'll turn it back to Patti for her closing remarks. And we look forward to seeing you at G2E.

headline: International Game Technology, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Eric. I hope you now understand why I am so confident that IGT is heading into some of the most dynamic times in its history. Technology is advancing rapidly in this industry, and I am certain that IGT will again lead the way. Before I share wit
componenttext:
Thanks, Eric. I hope you now understand why I am so confident that IGT is heading into some of the most dynamic times in its history. Technology is advancing rapidly in this industry, and I am certain that IGT will again lead the way. 
Before I share with you what all this means for our bottom line, let me first take some time to thank our employees. We have endured a dramatic period of change at IGT and within the industry. I have asked everyone in the corporation to be more efficient and to do more with less. To date, we've seen some pretty amazing results. 
That said, much of the well-hanging fruit have been harvested and some challenges still remain. I'm confident we will continue to achieve great things in working together. We will all share in the results. So thank you to everyone. 
In the long term, I believe we are well-positioned for top line growth with or without a meaningful change in the replacement levels in North America. I also believe that eventually, our customers will begin to focus on refreshing their slot floors to increase the differentiation of their entertainment offering. The timing is elusive. Therefore, at this time, I believe we must remain prudent and conservative, focusing on controlling that which we can control. 
For the current fiscal year '11, we offered GAAP earnings guidance of $0.77 to $0.87 per share, which is similar to our projections at this time a year ago. This is guidance that we are, at this time, confident in achieving. 
We also know that there is tremendous leverage in our business should demand for our products accelerate. While we have some lofty goals for this year, I must also point out the downside risks and uncertainties still exist, and that visibility is as limited as ever. 
In summary, we expect to see positive top line contributions in fiscal 2011 in the form of further International growth, leveraging our industry-leading MegaJackpots business, increasing our non-box revenues and garnering improved market share in new jurisdictions, domestically and abroad. We will continue to take advantage of our significant cash flows, further strengthening our balance sheet, investing in new technologies and leading the industry technologically as gaming transforms around the globe. 
We expect to improve our efficiencies and our focus on driving higher returns on our investments, lowering operating costs and harvesting stranded capital. And finally, we are confident that opportunities for replacement sales will return. When our customers meaningfully reinvest in their slot floors, they will turn to IGT as they always have, for leading products and technologies. 
And with that, we'd like to take your questions.

headline: International Game Technology, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2010
componenttextpreview: Patti, I think you mentioned that you're expecting your Gaming Ops yield to improve next year. What are some of the things that are driving that?
componenttext: Patti, I think you mentioned that you're expecting your Gaming Ops yield to improve next year. What are some of the things that are driving that?

headline: International Game Technology, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean, I think you'll see a lot of it at G2E. I mean, I think we really have the best Gaming Ops product lineup that we've had in many years that we're putting into the marketplace. So the first thing I would say is, yields in Gaming Ops are a comb
componenttext: Well, I mean, I think you'll see a lot of it at G2E. I mean, I think we really have the best Gaming Ops product lineup that we've had in many years that we're putting into the marketplace. So the first thing I would say is, yields in Gaming Ops are a combination of consumer discretionary spending and just rocking games. And I think this year, we have a really good lineup of games. We also are really deploying our strategy as a company around the reuse of hardware in the game ops space. So that we're not really pulling the hardware off of the floor, but there were software upgrading to the new games that we can push our lives of the hardware out longer, which should come back to you right from an earnings perspective. So I know it will be a combination of incredibly well-playing games, but moving to common hardware platform that are upgradable in the field as opposed to having you bring them off the floor.

componenttext: Yes, I would expect for the next couple of coming years that we would expect outside growth on international marketplaces. So I would expect to see the international business closing the gap a bit on the U.S. business, if you will. I would say in '11 and '12.

headline: International Game Technology, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, so I would say we're focused, as a management team, more on getting more from the installed base we have because it is stranded capital and it's a place we put capital to put incremental capital in without being able to be comfortable with the return
componenttext: Yes, so I would say we're focused, as a management team, more on getting more from the installed base we have because it is stranded capital and it's a place we put capital to put incremental capital in without being able to be comfortable with the return. It's like rather have my capital that’s deployed working harder first. So that's what we're focused on today. And I think it's a combination. When I think about yields, it's the combination of looking for a little bit of help from the economy and just putting better games out into the marketplace, replacing the bottom end of what is in the installed base today with higher-performing products. So a little bit of it will be mixed because we'll have higher performing mix assuming that nothing happens dramatically with Alabama. Alabama is the outlier. If we were to bring that back on, then I think you'll see a mix shift in the other direction, but we'll take that business.

headline: International Game Technology, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2010
componenttextpreview: Deploying better games may or may not have an immediate result in rate, but it provides a much more leverageable platform once the economy returns.
componenttext: Deploying better games may or may not have an immediate result in rate, but it provides a much more leverageable platform once the economy returns.

headline: International Game Technology, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, exactly.
componenttext: Yes, exactly.

headline: International Game Technology, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then if I look at your North American average sales price in the quarter, it looks to be down more year-over-year then sequentially up a little bit sequentially. But are you guys seeing a lot of competition? Do you say your competitors have been aggre
componenttext: And then if I look at your North American average sales price in the quarter, it looks to be down more year-over-year then sequentially up a little bit sequentially. But are you guys seeing a lot of competition? Do you say your competitors have been aggressive with discounting, and are you responding to that? Or do you feel like you are going out with what you have right now and it's more of a mix thing than it is competition?

headline: International Game Technology, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2010
componenttextpreview: This is Eric. Yes, there is -- the competition is fierce as it's been fierce for the last few years. Our competitors, we have a sense, are getting very aggressive. We're not going down that path. We think the value of our games is worth the price. And whi
componenttext: This is Eric. Yes, there is -- the competition is fierce as it's been fierce for the last few years. Our competitors, we have a sense, are getting very aggressive. We're not going down that path. We think the value of our games is worth the price. And while we have promotions and incentives, we really aren't looking to lower ASP.

headline: International Game Technology, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, and I think -- Carlo, this is Pat. If you look at year-on-year, Q4 of last year is when we first started growing out in earnest the MLD product which has the much higher ASP. And obviously, we were doing that in kind of a normal discount environment.
componenttext: Yes, and I think -- Carlo, this is Pat. If you look at year-on-year, Q4 of last year is when we first started growing out in earnest the MLD product which has the much higher ASP. And obviously, we were doing that in kind of a normal discount environment. This year's fourth quarter had a fair amount of MLD carryover from the dynamics promotion that ended the end of June, i.e. people have to have their orders in. Some of those orders came in Q4, and that's really what explains the lower ASP.

headline: International Game Technology, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2010
componenttextpreview: And next, we have a question from Mr. Steve Wieczynski with Stifel, Nicolaus.
componenttext: And next, we have a question from Mr. Steve Wieczynski with Stifel, Nicolaus.

headline: International Game Technology, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2010
componenttextpreview: In the Gaming Ops, with the net decrease of 1,800 units sequentially, how many of those came from Alabama?
componenttext: In the Gaming Ops, with the net decrease of 1,800 units sequentially, how many of those came from Alabama?

headline: International Game Technology, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think almost all, Mike (sic) [Steve]. There were roughly, I think there were 1,900 units left there at VictoryLand. That was the last property that closed, and it closed in August. So they're almost all of the -- in fact, you could assume the entire amo
componenttext: I think almost all, Mike (sic) [Steve]. There were roughly, I think there were 1,900 units left there at VictoryLand. That was the last property that closed, and it closed in August. So they're almost all of the -- in fact, you could assume the entire amount came from there. As well as pretty much -- we have a continual -- a lot of movement in and out of our installed base, as you might imagine. But both the year-on-year number, so the annual decrease and the quarterly decrease, largely Alabama.

headline: International Game Technology, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2010
componenttextpreview: Is it fair that -- do you think margins in the Game Ops will kind of trend here in the upper 50s assuming a normalized rate environment?
componenttext: Is it fair that -- do you think margins in the Game Ops will kind of trend here in the upper 50s assuming a normalized rate environment?

headline: International Game Technology, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think so. I think 58% to 60% is the right kind of range. We have a little bit of a downtick this quarter which is not unusual. Fourth quarters are always the time when a couple lot of stuff are usually going through the audit.
componenttext: Yes, I think so. I think 58% to 60% is the right kind of range. We have a little bit of a downtick this quarter which is not unusual. Fourth quarters are always the time when a couple lot of stuff are usually going through the audit.

headline: International Game Technology, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2010
componenttextpreview: Did you say you shipped any units to Cosmo this quarter?
componenttext: Did you say you shipped any units to Cosmo this quarter?

headline: International Game Technology, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2010
componenttextpreview: We did. We didn't recognize them, no.
componenttext: We did. We didn't recognize them, no.

headline: International Game Technology, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2010
componenttextpreview: So when we look at your ships share, I mean it looks to me just a little bit softer. And I think, what we are expecting, so is that kind of the difference there?
componenttext: So when we look at your ships share, I mean it looks to me just a little bit softer. And I think, what we are expecting, so is that kind of the difference there?

headline: International Game Technology, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, that would probably explain.
componenttext: Yes, that would probably explain.

headline: International Game Technology, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's part of it. I think when we look at the ship share go, Steve, I mean we really -- in the U.S., I mean we're kind of feeling like we're in that kind of 33%, 34% range. But when you really look at the focused activities that have been going on i
componenttext: Yes, that's part of it. I think when we look at the ship share go, Steve, I mean we really -- in the U.S., I mean we're kind of feeling like we're in that kind of 33%, 34% range. But when you really look at the focused activities that have been going on in the company, you really have to take it up a notch and we'll get the global ship share. So you line up our shift share on a global basis with WMS and Valley [ph] and we ship more than twice the closest competitor on a global basis. So that's where you, as an investor, get real operating leverage from IGT. It's really us pulling on every lever we have. And we just have some many more. So like Eric said, we have to go where the business is. So we're comfortable that when you look at the ship share on a global basis, which is the way we think about our business, right? We build the product. We ship it everywhere in the world. We're really comfortable with the representation we're getting in the marketplace.

headline: International Game Technology, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2010
componenttextpreview: And next, we have a call from Mr. Cameron McKnight of Buckingham.
componenttext: And next, we have a call from Mr. Cameron McKnight of Buckingham.

headline: International Game Technology, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just on your strategy going into the G2E, based on the press releases that have been coming out, it looks like you're shifting product back towards more branded and theme-based games?
componenttext: Just on your strategy going into the G2E, based on the press releases that have been coming out, it looks like you're shifting product back towards more branded and theme-based games?

headline: International Game Technology, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2010
componenttextpreview: I don't know if that's an unusual trend for us. We've always believed that the branded games attract customers to sit down. You still have to have great math and great games to keep them in the seat, but I don't think that's anything unusual for us.
componenttext: I don't know if that's an unusual trend for us. We've always believed that the branded games attract customers to sit down. You still have to have great math and great games to keep them in the seat, but I don't think that's anything unusual for us.

headline: International Game Technology, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. Cameron, I think it's interesting because it's the branded games that play best in the press release always. So you have to be careful about doing a press release on something that no one never heard of. But having said that a lot of time in the last
componenttext: Yes. Cameron, I think it's interesting because it's the branded games that play best in the press release always. So you have to be careful about doing a press release on something that no one never heard of. But having said that a lot of time in the last two weeks in the pre-G2E previews with our customers, I can tell you that some of the non-branded IGT-created games are getting incredible feedback. So I think for us, again, it's about portfolio management. So we've got to have the big brand. We've got to have the themes, but we've got to fill in all around it. And I think, Eric talked about this Reel Edge product which we had one customer that ordered the product right on the showroom floor, which haven't happened for us in a while, when they saw the Reel Edge product. So I think it really is about the portfolio management. The things that get printed are all about the big theme games, but the things we're building are really touch of broader base.

headline: International Game Technology, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2010
componenttextpreview: On the replacement market, WMS made some comments that they were seeing some very early and cautious optimism from customers as far as replacements are concerned. Have you been sensing the same from some of your discussions?
componenttext: On the replacement market, WMS made some comments that they were seeing some very early and cautious optimism from customers as far as replacements are concerned. Have you been sensing the same from some of your discussions?

headline: International Game Technology, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, we've been very busy visiting customers, Patti and I, over the past several quarters. I would say that they are optimistic, but we get no visibility on when they're going to start spending. So I think they feel better. But we don't get a sense that
componenttext: Well, we've been very busy visiting customers, Patti and I, over the past several quarters. I would say that they are optimistic, but we get no visibility on when they're going to start spending. So I think they feel better. But we don't get a sense that they're spending soon.

headline: International Game Technology, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think that they're all waiting for different signs. It depends on who it is. I mean I had one customer say to me last week in the showroom, "You know you have great games. I wish I could buy them today." So it's kind of interesting that I think the
componenttext: Yes, I think that they're all waiting for different signs. It depends on who it is. I mean I had one customer say to me last week in the showroom, "You know you have great games. I wish I could buy them today." So it's kind of interesting that I think they're all feeling that need and there's this just giant pent-up demand, but they have their own obligations that they have to meet internally. So they're walking that fine line. So our responsibility is to go where people are spending, which I think is what you see in our results this quarter and to position ourselves for those when the spending comes back, to have the best products in the market. And that's really what we're focused on. So we hear good things, but then we want to see -- it's like show me the money. I'm the Patti Hart, show me the money, CEO right now. We'll see.

headline: International Game Technology, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then finally on the balance sheet, do you have any intentions of restructuring things there or trying to take out and convert?
componenttext: And then finally on the balance sheet, do you have any intentions of restructuring things there or trying to take out and convert?

headline: International Game Technology, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2010
componenttextpreview: Actually, we're studying all of that right now, Cameron. Because the rate we generate cash, we don't have any pre-payable debt before too much longer. So part of analysis is being done at this time around that.
componenttext: Actually, we're studying all of that right now, Cameron. Because the rate we generate cash, we don't have any pre-payable debt before too much longer. So part of analysis is being done at this time around that.

headline: International Game Technology, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2010
componenttextpreview: David Katz with Jefferies & Company.
componenttext: David Katz with Jefferies & Company.

headline: International Game Technology, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2010
componenttextpreview: Patti, just thinking about your approach, and I don't recall exactly what the dates are but one of the mandates I think you issued when you started was getting new product to market in a good amount of time. Are you pleased, satisfied or is there more wor
componenttext: Patti, just thinking about your approach, and I don't recall exactly what the dates are but one of the mandates I think you issued when you started was getting new product to market in a good amount of time. Are you pleased, satisfied or is there more work to do in terms of getting new games out sort of on the shelf that can be purchased when they are? And then I just have one housekeeping follow-up, please.

headline: International Game Technology, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sure. I would say I am incredibly pleased with the progress. I will never think the work is done, right? That is my responsibility, is to keep that pressure on. So I'm incredibly pleased with the progress that we're making, not only in our feed to market
componenttext: Sure. I would say I am incredibly pleased with the progress. I will never think the work is done, right? That is my responsibility, is to keep that pressure on. So I'm incredibly pleased with the progress that we're making, not only in our feed to market in developing the product, but our feed to market in manufacturing and delivering the product. So if you look at not only the development cycle, but the order, the revenue cycle has been dramatically improved. And you see it in our inventory turns, you see it in the way we really exercise the working capital in the company. So it's that full cycle from development of a product to having it on the floor generating revenue for us and our customers. I'm very pleased with the time we've taken out of that process. Next year's -- we're continuing to mine that process because there's more work to be done. There's much more work to be done and there's the complexity of the product increases, which is and we'll continue to do. Yet to keep your eye on that, make sure that it doesn't really float back out in development time. So very happy with progress, but for my employees that are out there listening, more work to be done.

headline: International Game Technology, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2010
componenttextpreview: What was the turn-time on order shipment when you started and where is it today? Is there any detail you could give us with that?
componenttext: What was the turn-time on order shipment when you started and where is it today? Is there any detail you could give us with that?

headline: International Game Technology, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think we've taken about 20% out of the process, actually. So we haven't really made public the details, but we are down 20% in order to revenue from where we were 18 months ago.
componenttext: Yes, I think we've taken about 20% out of the process, actually. So we haven't really made public the details, but we are down 20% in order to revenue from where we were 18 months ago.

headline: International Game Technology, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our focus on delivering products to market naturally is first focused on the MegaJackpots business because time is money in that business. The faster you get, the better game on the floor, the faster it starts to earn revenue. What I'm harking about, rein
componenttext: Our focus on delivering products to market naturally is first focused on the MegaJackpots business because time is money in that business. The faster you get, the better game on the floor, the faster it starts to earn revenue. What I'm harking about, reinforcing what Patti has said, is in our process of game development, a lot of the improvements are structural in a sense that we've deployed tools that allow the game developed to be more effective. In the order to delivery process, we have a lot more process definition, a lot more process improvement and it has driven that speed to market. So like Patti said, not done yet, but still work in progress, but excellent, good progress.

headline: International Game Technology, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, good progress.
componenttext: Yes, good progress.

headline: International Game Technology, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2010
componenttextpreview: Now, in the past, you've talked about the Game Ops segment and what we referred to as mix issues and my sense is that there was some leasing of games going on with certain customers. When you comment today about the yield on your installed base improving,
componenttext: Now, in the past, you've talked about the Game Ops segment and what we referred to as mix issues and my sense is that there was some leasing of games going on with certain customers. When you comment today about the yield on your installed base improving, does that suggest that some of those mixed issues are past, or are you eclipsing those, and how do we think about that? And then just my one last detail is what kind of tax rate are you assuming in the guidance?

headline: International Game Technology, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, Dave, this is Pat. I think that the mix issues, we're always going to have that challenge because we're creating products in all of those categories. And sometimes you have a product in one -- say, you take wide-area progressive versus stand-alone. A
componenttext: Yes, Dave, this is Pat. I think that the mix issues, we're always going to have that challenge because we're creating products in all of those categories. And sometimes you have a product in one -- say, you take wide-area progressive versus stand-alone. And sometimes, you'll have a very dynamic product that really drives some of that shift. But I think the thing we're encouraged by is that the yields are starting to stabilize. And the pipeline of games that we have, we've got a real renewed focus, intense focus on WAP and stand-alone so that no one product category gets ignored, which I think in times past, the times we've shift a little bit too far in one direction, either the product sales or at the expense of Game Ops or vice versa, and I think now given that we have two individuals in charge of both of those, there is intense focus on both. And then relative to the tax rate, on a go-forward basis, I think about 39%.

headline: International Game Technology, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, and I think it's also important to note on the Game Ops yield that when we're managing Game Ops at the consolidated level from a yield perspective. What we don't want to do is put so much focus on that yield number that we don't purchase to take in j
componenttext: Yes, and I think it's also important to note on the Game Ops yield that when we're managing Game Ops at the consolidated level from a yield perspective. What we don't want to do is put so much focus on that yield number that we don't purchase to take in jurisdictional expansion. So a lot of the opportunities to enter new jurisdictions come at the low yielding product levels. And so using that as a way to enter market is a really important strategy that has served IGT so well historically. And so keeping our focus on the sub-segments, if you will, of Game Ops, but thinking about it at a consolidated level in a way that is always a trade-off between participating and entering new markets with holding up the high-end performing games in the MegaJackpots sector.

headline: International Game Technology, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2010
componenttextpreview: And our last question comes from Ryan Worst with Brean Murray.
componenttext: And our last question comes from Ryan Worst with Brean Murray.

headline: International Game Technology, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2010
componenttextpreview: Could you guys provide a breakdown of the North American units recognized between new and replacement, 3,300 was the number?
componenttext: Could you guys provide a breakdown of the North American units recognized between new and replacement, 3,300 was the number?

headline: International Game Technology, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think even though we did it in the press release, I think it's fair to assume that the vast majority of these would be replaced. It's generally when we have deferred revenue, it's on the new units.
componenttext: I think even though we did it in the press release, I think it's fair to assume that the vast majority of these would be replaced. It's generally when we have deferred revenue, it's on the new units.

headline: International Game Technology, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then, Pat, could you talk about the timing of the recognition to gain sales to Cosmo? Is it going to be kind of like an OREO deal where you recognize it over a length of time?
componenttext: And then, Pat, could you talk about the timing of the recognition to gain sales to Cosmo? Is it going to be kind of like an OREO deal where you recognize it over a length of time?

headline: International Game Technology, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, I believe most of it will probably happen in accordance with the opening because a lot of it is tied because of the software.
componenttext: No, I believe most of it will probably happen in accordance with the opening because a lot of it is tied because of the software.

headline: International Game Technology, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, contractually, we cut our teeth on the OREO contract. And I think we're a little bit more focused on revenue recognition in subsequent contracts. So I think you'll see this one will contractually allow us to recognize revenue in a different fashion.
componenttext: Yes, contractually, we cut our teeth on the OREO contract. And I think we're a little bit more focused on revenue recognition in subsequent contracts. So I think you'll see this one will contractually allow us to recognize revenue in a different fashion.

headline: International Game Technology, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then could you talk about the international Gaming Ops revenue? It looked like you were down year-over-year versus up in the previous two quarters. Could you talk about the change there? Is it just FX?
componenttext: And then could you talk about the international Gaming Ops revenue? It looked like you were down year-over-year versus up in the previous two quarters. Could you talk about the change there? Is it just FX?

headline: International Game Technology, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, were up year-on-year but down in the quarter. And I'm trying to remember, I think it has something to do a little bit with the shift in mix because we're kind of transitioning to Class III. I think it's more of a temporary blip as opposed to a trend.
componenttext: Yes, were up year-on-year but down in the quarter. And I'm trying to remember, I think it has something to do a little bit with the shift in mix because we're kind of transitioning to Class III. I think it's more of a temporary blip as opposed to a trend.

headline: International Game Technology, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2010
componenttextpreview: So are most of the Class III payments in Mexico, are they going to be revenue share as well? And do you expect to convert your entire Class II base to Class III games over the next year or so or how long will that...
componenttext: So are most of the Class III payments in Mexico, are they going to be revenue share as well? And do you expect to convert your entire Class II base to Class III games over the next year or so or how long will that...

headline: International Game Technology, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2010
componenttextpreview: First, to your first question, I think the answer is yes, so probably most will rev share. And I would assume that most of that Class II base does transition over the next 12 to 18 months, I would assume.
componenttext: First, to your first question, I think the answer is yes, so probably most will rev share. And I would assume that most of that Class II base does transition over the next 12 to 18 months, I would assume.

headline: International Game Technology, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, with that, thank you very much for joining us today. We are celebrating the end of 2010, launching ourselves into 2011. We really appreciate you taking the time out to spend some of that time with us and hear our story. So thanks very much, everyone
componenttext: Well, with that, thank you very much for joining us today. We are celebrating the end of 2010, launching ourselves into 2011. We really appreciate you taking the time out to spend some of that time with us and hear our story. So thanks very much, everyone.
